Adrastos.description: Phrygian prince who accidentally killed his brother and later Atys, son of Croesus.

Alexander.description: King of Macedon who served as a Persian vassal but secretly aided the Greeks.

Amasis.description: Pharaoh of Egypt, the last great ruler before the Persian conquest.

Amestris.description: Queen of Persia and wife of Xerxes I, known for her cruelty.

Amyntas.description: King of Macedon and father of Alexander I.

Anaxandrides.description: King of Sparta and father of Leonidas I.

Apis.description: Sacred bull worshipped in the Memphis region of Egypt.

Apollo.description: Olympian god of prophecy, music, and healing, speaking through the Oracle.

Argos.description: Citizens of Argos, a major city-state in the Peloponnese.

Aristagoras.description: Tyrant of Miletus who instigated the Ionian Revolt against Persia.

Aristeides.description: Athenian statesman and general, known as 'The Just'.

Ariston.description: King of Sparta and father of Demaratus.

Artabanos.description: Brother of Darius I and uncle of Xerxes, known for his wise counsel.

Artaphrenes.description: Persian satrap of Sardis and brother of Darius I.

Artemisia.description: Queen of Halicarnassus who commanded ships for Xerxes at Salamis.

Astyages.description: Last king of the Median Empire and grandfather of Cyrus the Great.

Athenian.description: Citizens of Athens, the cradle of democracy and key player in the Persian Wars.

Atossa.description: Persian queen, daughter of Cyrus, wife of Darius, and mother of Xerxes.

Cambyses.description: King of Kings of Persia who conquered Egypt, son of Cyrus.

Candaules.description: King of Lydia who was betrayed by his wife and Gyges.

Cleomenes.description: Agiad King of Sparta known for his aggressive foreign policy.

Corinth.description: Citizens of Corinth, a wealthy Greek city-state.

Croesus.description: King of Lydia renowned for his wealth, defeated by Cyrus.

Cyrus.description: Founder of the Achaemenid Empire and conqueror of Babylon.

Dareios.description: King of Kings who organized the Persian Empire and launched the first invasion of Greece.

Delphians.description: Inhabitants of Delphi, guardians of the Oracle.

Demaratos.description: Exiled King of Sparta who accompanied Xerxes in his invasion of Greece.

Dionysios.description: Phocaean commander at the Battle of Lade.

Egyptians.description: People of the Nile, known for their ancient wisdom and customs.

Ethiopian.description: Ruler of the long-lived Ethiopians who defied Cambyses.

Eurybiades.description: Spartan commander of the Greek navy at Salamis.

Gelon.description: Tyrant of Syracuse who defeated the Carthaginians.

Gobryas.description: One of the seven conspirators who overthrew the Magian and father-in-law of Darius.

Gyges.description: Bodyguard who seized the Lydian throne after killing Candaules.

Harpagos.description: Median general who saved the infant Cyrus and later helped him overthrow Astyages.

Heracles.description: Divine hero and son of Zeus, ancestor of the Spartan kings.

Hermotimos.description: Eunuch who took brutal revenge on the man who castrated him.

Hipparchos.description: Son of Peisistratos and tyrant of Athens, assassinated by the Tyrannicides.

Hippocleides.description: Athenian noble who 'danced away his marriage'.

Histiaios.description: Tyrant of Miletus who instigated the Ionian Revolt.

Homer.description: Legendary poet, author of the Iliad and the Odyssey.

Leonidas.description: King of Sparta who died defending the pass at Thermopylae.

Lycophron.description: Son of Periander who was estranged from his father.

Lydians.description: People of Lydia, known for their wealth and invention of coinage.

Magian.description: Imposter who seized the Persian throne (also known as Gaumata).

Magians.description: Priestly caste of the Medes and Persians.

Mardonios.description: Persian military commander who led the invasion of Greece under Xerxes.

Masistes.description: Brother of Xerxes I, involved in a tragic family intrigue.

Megabazos.description: Highly respected Persian general under Darius I.

Miletos.description: Citizens of Miletus, the leading city of Ionia.

Miltiades.description: Athenian general who devised the strategy at the Battle of Marathon.

Octamasades.description: Scythian king who executed his brother Scyles.

Oibares.description: Groom of Darius I who helped him win the throne via a horse trick.

Oracles.description: Various prophetic shrines consulted by the Greeks.

Orestes.description: Son of Agamemnon whose bones were sought by the Spartans.

Oroites.description: Persian satrap of Sardis who treacherously killed Polycrates.

Otanes.description: Persian noble who initiated the conspiracy against the Magian.

Pausanias.description: Spartan regent and general who commanded the Greeks at Plataea.

Pheidippides.description: Athenian courier sent to Sparta to ask for help before Marathon.

Phrygia.description: Phrygian prince who accidentally killed his brother and later Atys, son of Croesus.

Polycrates.description: Powerful tyrant of Samos known for his 'Ring of Polycrates'.

Prexaspes.description: Persian noble who killed Smerdis on Cambyses' orders.

Proteus.description: Egyptian king who detained Helen of Troy.

Pythian.description: The High Priestess of the Temple of Apollo at Delphi.

The Pythia.description: The High Priestess of the Temple of Apollo at Delphi.

Pythios.description: Lydian of immense wealth who entertained Xerxes.

Samians.description: Inhabitants of the island of Samos.

Scythians.description: Nomadic people of the Pontic-Caspian steppe.

Smerdis.description: Son of Cyrus the Great, allegedly killed by his brother Cambyses.

Socles.description: Corinthian delegate who spoke against restoring tyranny in Athens.

Spartans.description: Citizens of Sparta, famous for their military prowess.

Syagros.description: Spartan envoy who objected to Gelon's command.

Syloson.description: Brother of Polycrates who was restored to Samos by Darius.

Tegeans.description: Citizens of Tegea, often rivals of Sparta.

Tellos.description: Athenian citizen whom Solon declared the happiest of men.

Thebans.description: Citizens of Thebes, a major Boeotian city.

Themistocles.description: Athenian politician and general who built the navy.

Thespians.description: Citizens of Thespiae who stayed with Leonidas at Thermopylae.

Thessalians.description: Inhabitants of Thessaly, known for their cavalry.

Thrasydeios.description: Tyrant of Akragas and son of Theron.

Timagenides.description: Theban leader who collaborated with the Persians.

Xerxes.description: King of Kings of Persia who led the massive invasion of Greece.

Zeus.description: King of the gods of Mount Olympus.

Simonides.description: Greek lyric poet who composed the famous Thermopylae epitaph.

Dienekes.description: A Spartan soldier at Thermopylae, famous for his wit and bravery.
